div.p: My friendly greeting, also whatever I can offer in honor, love, and goodness, may it always be ready for you from me, pious, well-learned, distinguished, wise, especially kind, honorable, dear sir. I have received your friendly letter along with the sent sermons, for which I thank you greatly. And so that I can show some gratitude for your goodness and friendliness in some way, since I have received an uncertain message, I wanted to send you this cheese, with the request to accept it with the best intentions from me and to consider me, as always, at your service. I will pray to God for your well-being, and that He may keep you in health and long life, and I will strive to serve you.
Dated from Aarwangen, June 19, 1570. Your willing servant Hans Rudolf Hagenberg.
"Former bailiff of Lenzburg, now bailiff of Aarwangen and again appointed to the council in Bern for the office of banneret.
To the well-learned, pious, distinguished, honorable, wise master Heinrich Bullinger, preacher in Zurich, my especially kind, honorable, dear sir.
"H. Hans Rudolf Hagenberg, bailiff of Aarwangen."
